item.title: American Brewing: IBUs and ABV
item.description: beer <- read_csv("/home/datys/Downloads/beers.csv") ## Warning: Missing column names filled in: 'X1' [1] ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## X1 = col_integer(), ## abv = col_double(), ## ibu = col_double(), ## id = col_integer(), ## name = col_character(), ## style = col_character(), ## brewery_id = col_integer(), ## ounces = col_double() ## ) popular_beers <- beer %>% filter(style %in% c("American IPA", "American Brown Ale", "American Porter", "American Pale Ale (APA)", "Witbier", "American Amber / Red Ale", "American Blond Ale")) %>% filter(!

item.description: beer <- read_csv("/home/datys/Downloads/beers.csv") ## Warning: Missing column names filled in: 'X1' [1] ## Parsed with column specification: ## cols( ## X1 = col_integer(), ## abv = col_double(), ## ibu = col_double(), ## id = col_integer(), ## name = col_character(), ## style = col_character(), ## brewery_id = col_integer(), ## ounces = col_double() ## ) popular_beers <- beer %>% filter(style %in% c("American IPA", "American Brown Ale", "American Porter", "American Pale Ale (APA)", "Witbier", "American Amber / Red Ale", "American Blond Ale")) %>% filter(!

item.title: Gapminder: Continental Life Expectancies
item.description: Here we take a look at countries with low life expectancy across continents. gapm <- gapminder gapm_lifeexp <- gapm %>% group_by(year, continent) %>% filter(lifeExp <= quantile(lifeExp, .25)) %>% arrange(continent, year, lifeExp) gapm_lifeexp <- gapm_lifeexp %>% filter(continent != 'Oceania') ggplot(gapm_lifeexp, aes(x = year, y = lifeExp, color = continent)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.2) + geom_smooth(method = 'lm', se = FALSE, alpha = 1) + scale_color_brewer(type = 'qual', palette = 2) Type of Graph This is a scatter plot with linear fit lines.

item.title: Gapminder: GDP Per Capita
item.description: Here we take a look at country GDP per capita across different continents from 1950 to present. gapm <- gapminder gapm_gdpextrema <- gapm %>% group_by(continent, year) %>% filter(gdpPercap == max(gdpPercap) | gdpPercap == min(gdpPercap)) %>% mutate(extrema = factor(case_when(gdpPercap == max(gdpPercap) ~ 'max', gdpPercap == min(gdpPercap) ~ 'min'))) %>% arrange(continent, country, year, gdpPercap) gapm_gdpextrema_notasia <- gapm_gdpextrema %>% filter(continent != 'Asia') gapm_gdpextrema_asia <- gapm_gdpextrema %>% filter(continent == 'Asia') p1 <- ggplot(gapm_gdpextrema_notasia, aes(x = year, y = gdpPercap, color = continent)) + geom_point(alpha = 0.

item.title: About Me
item.description: Darrick Sturgeon Work I work full-time as a Senior Research Assistant in a Neuroimaging lab at OHSU, with an emphasis on image processing. I oversee and advise on a number of tailored MRI processing pipelines on macaques, rodents, and both human adults and neonates. In addition to image processing, I also assist with software and computational problems, such as designing secure ETL pipelines for medical research databases and implementing software for stastical/machine learning analyses on neuroimaging data.

item.title: A small project example : add yours !
item.description: Along with Ford Prefect, Dent barely escapes the Earth’s destruction as it is demolished to make way for a hyperspace bypass. Arthur spends the next several years, still wearing his dressing gown, helplessly launched from crisis to crisis while trying to straighten out his lifestyle. He rather enjoys tea, but seems to have trouble obtaining it in the far reaches of the galaxy. In time, he learns how to fly and carves a niche for himself as a sandwich-maker.

item.title: Projects
item.description: In this theme, it is possible to add sections like a Projects one for example. You can add plenty of articles about your projects and a presentation page that will be displayed before the list. All is modulable, if you don’t want something. A Hollywood-funded film version, produced and filmed in the UK, was released in April 2005, and radio adaptations of the third, fourth, and fifth novels were broadcast from 2004 to 2005.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can embed an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.00 ## Mean :15.4 Mean : 42.98 ## 3rd Qu.

item.title: Creating a New Theme
item.description: Introduction This tutorial will show you how to create a simple theme in Hugo. I assume that you are familiar with HTML, the bash command line, and that you are comfortable using Markdown to format content. I’ll explain how Hugo uses templates and how you can organize your templates to create a theme. I won’t cover using CSS to style your theme. We’ll start with creating a new site with a very basic template.

item.title: (Hu)go Template Primer
item.description: Hugo uses the excellent go html/template library for its template engine. It is an extremely lightweight engine that provides a very small amount of logic. In our experience that it is just the right amount of logic to be able to create a good static website. If you have used other template systems from different languages or frameworks you will find a lot of similarities in go templates. This document is a brief primer on using go templates.

item.title: Getting Started with Hugo
item.description: Step 1. Install Hugo Goto hugo releases and download the appropriate version for your os and architecture. Save it somewhere specific as we will be using it in the next step. More complete instructions are available at installing hugo Step 2. Build the Docs Hugo has its own example site which happens to also be the documentation site you are reading right now. Follow the following steps: Clone the hugo repository Go into the repo Run hugo in server mode and build the docs Open your browser to http://localhost:1313 Corresponding pseudo commands:
